labels.analysis: The MCP Server described is primarily focused on time tracking and management through FreeAgent's timeslips and timers. It provides tools to list, create, update, delete, and manage timeslips, as well as start and stop timers associated with these timeslips. This suggests a strong emphasis on time-tracking and project management, particularly within workflows that involve billing or productivity tracking.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "Daily Productivity" is chosen because the server's core functionality revolves around managing time, which is a critical aspect of personal and professional productivity. The secondary label "File Management" is included because timeslips can be seen as a form of data handling, though this is not the server's primary purpose. The custom "Time Tracking" label is added because the server's unique focus on timeslips and timers is specialized beyond the scope of general productivity tools.

remote_server_response.error: unhandled errors in a TaskGroup (1 sub-exception)

server_info_crawled.name: FreeAgent Server
server_info_crawled.author: @markpitt/freeagent-mcp
server_info_crawled.overview: Manage your FreeAgent timeslips and timers effortlessly. Track time, create and update timeslips, and control timers directly from your applications. Simplify your time management with seamless integration into your workflow.

tools.name: list_timeslips
tools.description: Deploy Server FreeAgent Server Claim Server @markpitt/freeagent-mcp Try in Playground list_timeslips

tools.name: get_timeslip
tools.description: Get a single timeslip by ID

tools.name: start_timer
tools.description: Start a timer for a timeslip

tools.name: stop_timer
tools.description: Stop a running timer for a timeslip

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@markpitt/freeagent-mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
